definition[0]: an object that floats on the sea, a lake etc to mark a safe or dangerous area
definition[1]: to make someone feel happier or more confident
example[0]: The party is buoyed up by the latest opinion poll results.
definition[2]: to keep profits, prices etc at a high level
example[1]: Increased demand for computers buoyed their profits.
definition[4]: if the market or prices are buoyed, people feel confident and buy stocks and shares, and prices rise
example[2]: In Britain, bond prices were buoyed by a rise in the pound.
example[3]: The market was buoyed by gains in some large telecommunications shares.
